title: Testing callout blocks
text:
See the documentation.






Note



Note that there are five types of callouts, including: note, warning, important, tip, and caution.








Warning



Don’t do that! simple appearance.








Important



Do do this!








Tip With Caption



This is an example of a callout with a caption.








Expand To Learn About Collapse





This is an example of a ‘folded’ caution callout that can be expanded by the user. You can use collapse="true" to collapse it by default or collapse="false" to make a collapsible callout that is expanded by default.









Don’t do that! simple appearance.









Don’t do that! minimal appearance.

title: Syntax Highlighting
text:
#| label: code-demo-py
#| eval: false
#| message: false
#| warning: false

import numpy as np


Toggle the code
library(dplyr)
library(palmerpenguins)

penguins %>%
  mutate(
    long_flipper = case_when(
      species == "Adelie" & flipper_length_mm > 195 ~ TRUE,
      species == "Chinstrap" & flipper_length_mm > 200 ~ TRUE,
      species == "Gentoo" & flipper_length_mm > 225 ~ TRUE,
      TRUE ~ FALSE
    )
  )

title: Experimenting with icon links
text:
Experimenting with distilltools::icon_link in Quarto



In a code block puts them all on separate lines.


 slides


 materials


 video


But using inline chunks gets them on the same line (as long as there are no line breaks between them):
 slides  materials  video
also, note, need display: inline-block in the css

title: Experimenting with icon links
text:
Using btn and svg




materials





materials 2

title: Experimenting with icon links
text:
Conclusion
Original strategy, <a> styled to look like button, is probably best (see this StackOverflow).
Also, use <i> rather than <svg> as that’s what Quarto seems to do (though note can style <svg> with CSS).
Also, using font-size CSS property makes both icon and text bigger with <i> tag, but not <svg>.
